Dates.notes: Date spoken by moderator George Young at beginning of recording.

Notes.note:
For more information, see the article "Computers to change book form?" from Citizen Book editor, Burt Heward's column, "Cover to Cover" in The Ottawa Citizen, October 19, 1985. https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/464365037/
Transcription of "Computers to change book form?": 
"Ottawa's fourth annual Festival of the Arts is getting its biggest boost ever from the book community, specially the debate today between literary critics Frank Davey of York University and Robin Mathews of Carleton University.
The first of the five lively events under the WordWorks title, the debate between computer-advocate Davey and nationalist Mathews, promises fireworks. It was to begin at 1 p.m. today in the Ottawa Public Library auditorium, Metcalfe and Laurier.
Author Mathews operates a traditional small publishing operation, Steel Rail Press, while poet Davey is founder of Swift Current, a computer network for writers. Most appropriately for them, the topic is 'Whither the Book?'
'I have opposed the Mathews style of nationalism, Davey said earlier, 'because it assumes a single definition of Canadian culture. It seems to stem from a United Empire Loyalist tradition that may be valid in Ontario, but is not in the West.'
Davey said he prefers a Diefenbaker-style 'community of communities ... an accumulation of regional artistic cultures.'
Mathews's traditional views reflect a central stream of Canadian literature and valid concerns--shared by Davey--about the nation's cultural survival. Steel Rail next month launches Ottawa poet Patrick White's long poem in honor of a Chilean leftist martyr, Homage to Victor Jara (paperback, $7.95). It includes translation into Spanish by Ottawa Cuban-Canadian Juan O'Neil.
Do books, as we know them, have a future?
Davey offers a radical view that publishers will lose their power to decide the number of copies, the type of paper and the cost of books as readers assume authority.
'With the computer,' said Davey, 'you can actually send the text of the book to a bookstore and have the printing done there and the reader could determine there all the things decided by the publisher.'
Davey said the bookstore printings to suit individuals could vary from cheap formats to some approaching medieval manuscripts in appeal and quality.
Canada Council partly funds Swift Current, 'an electronic literary magazine' in which each of 40 Canadian writers edits his or her own contribution to the large data bank (Vax-750 operated by York University).
'We offer every reader an option of deleting not only an individual work but an individual author from his or her own view of the data base,' said Davey. Writers participate free in return for their writing and editing work. The 40 subscribers, so far, pay $25 (individuals) or $100 (libraries and other institutions). For classroom study, subscribers can pay for printouts at three cents for 50 lines (about 60 cents for 20 pages)--'a nominal fee.'
Swift Current gives regions and individuals an  escape from 'centralizing forces,' and Canadian writers a seawall against the flood of U.S. culture."

Content.notes: Contents entry temporary.
Content.contents: Debate and reading held on October 19th, 1985 at the Ottawa Public Library between Robin Mathews (Professor at Carleton University) and Frank Davey (Head of English Dept at York University in Toronto). The debate was moderated and recorded by George Young, sponsored by the Canadian Book Publishing Council, and organized by the Council for the Arts in Ottawa. The event consists of a reading by Robin Mathews, then a reading by Frank Davey, and then a debate.

Creators.name: Council for the Arts in Ottawa

Content.contents: This tape consists of an interview by George Bowering of Daphne Marlatt discussing her new novel, Ana Historic, and reading selections from the text. The interview was recorded by CiTR FM at UBC, Vancouver, B.C., Canada. This pre-recorded interview was aired by CFUV FM at the University of Victoria on the campus radio program Coast to Coast: Canada's Underground Literary Review with Jim Andrews. The interview was likely pre-recorded ca. 1988, after Ana Historic was first published.

Charles Olson, Robert Creeley, Robert Duncan, Allen Ginsberg, Margaret Avison, and Denise Levertov Monday morning discussion on "intention" and "induced hypersensitivity," August 5, 1963. Tape also includes Allen Ginberg reading on November 26, 1963 (sponsored by Auerhahn Press), and Allen Ginsberg reading "Wichita Vortex Sutra" (recorded from KGED program) in July 1966. Recordist unknown.

Malaspina College and The Canada Council present FRED WAH Thursday, February 3, 1972, Room 108 8:00 P.M.
Fred Wah was born in Swift Current, Saskatchewan, and at an early age moved to the Kootenays. He attended UBC where he was one of the editors of a poetry newsletter, Tish, and later edited a poetry newsletter, Sum, at the University of New Mexico. He later attended the State University of New York at Buffalo where he was one of the editors of a poetry journal, Magazine of Further Studies. Since 1967, he has been teaching at Selkirk College in Castlegar. His immediate concerns are with an experimental first-year university program which he coordinates (Arts I), and also to map, in poems, the geography of the land which has played such a prominent part in his life. Fred has had two volumes of poetry published - Lardeau, in 1965, and Mountain, in 1967. Coach House Press will be issuing a new collection of his this coming April.

Gyseman, and introduced by Roy Miki and Warren Tallman. The six poets include Fred Wah, Brian Fawcett, Robin Blaser, Lionel Kearns, Daphne Marlatt, and George Bowering.

Side A consists of short clips of home recordings of a two-year-old Thea Bowering talking with George and Angela Bowering. Recorded between January and February 1973.

Side B consists of a home recorded interview of Louis Dudek, perhaps by Angela Bowering in 1970 in Montreal.

Content.notes: Contents entry temporary.
Content.contents:
Side A consists of a home recording of Thea Bowering editing an audio draft of "Jeanne's Monologue." Bowering is heard singing along to the music of Van Morrison, reading an excerpt from Anne Carson's poem "The Glass Essay," and editing a draft of "Jeanne's Monologue" on the computer.

Side B consists of Sheila Watson reading selections from The Double Hook and discussing passages at a public reading. The date, location, and name of this event is unknown.

Creators.name: Watson, Sheila
Creators.notes: Sheila Watson reads selections from The Double Hook and discusses them on side B of this recording.

Creators.name: Bowering, Thea
Creators.notes: On Side A of this recording Thea Bowering is heard recording an audio draft of "Jeanne's Monologue."

Related_Works.citation: Bowering, Thea. "Jeanne's Monologue." Love at Last Sight: Stories. NeWest Press, 2013, pp. 79-110.

Content.contents:
Side A consists of a selection of commercial music.

The first part of Side B consists of George Bowering recording a poetry reading, perhaps of his students reading their own work. The tape then contains a conversation between George Bowering, Angela Bowering, Malcolm [?], and an unidentified female speaker. There are also excerpts from a different conversation between George Bowering, Angela Bowering, and an unidentified speaker with an Australian accent, possibly known as Tony from other recordings (2019.003.013).

Digital_File_Description.contents: Explaining purpose of this course - looking at transgressive poetry. Also references small Vancouver feminist poetry magazines including 'However', 'Flip', and 'Six'. Discusses Charles Olson.

Edgar Allen Poe's history - receiving poetry prize while Poe was being held in an asylum to avoid the charge of treason. Connection to Ezra Pound. Discussion of William Carlos Williams as critic (writing himself out of the power structure).

Digital_File_Description.contents: Discussiong of Robert Duncan manuscripts that draw from the works of Gertrude Stein. Mentions W.A.C. Bennett of Kelowna (historically significant figure in the Okanagan). Also discusses works of William Carlos Williams (particularly "Spring and All").
Formal principles within poetics - discusses coherence and cohesion as counter-terms within poetry. Gertrude Stein and James Joyce as viewing the canonical discourse externally.

Dates.notes: Warren Tallman references this event in his retirement speech, "How To Play Career and Win" (In the Midst, 253).

Content.contents: This recording contains the audio from a public event hosted and performed by the graduate students of Warren Tallman's Walt Whitman English class in 1967. The poetry reading consists of approximately 12 students reading the poems and prose of Walt Whitman. Commercially recorded Civil War music is also played during a short intermission during the reading.

Creators.name: Tallman, Warren
Creators.notes: Class professor and organizer of the reading

Contributors.name: Whitman, Walt
Contributors.notes: Whitman's poetry is read by students in this recording.

Contributors.name: García Lorca, Federico
Contributors.notes: Lorca's poetry is read by a student in this recording.

Contributors.name: Crane, Hart
Contributors.notes: Crane's poetry is read by a student in this recording.

Contributors.name: Emerson, Ralph Waldo
Contributors.notes: Letters from Emerson to Whitman are read by students in this recording.

Contributors.name: James, Henry
Contributors.notes: A letter from James to Whitman is read by a student in this recording.

Related_Works.citation: Crane, Hart. "IV. Cape Hatteras." The Bridge.
Emerson, Ralph Waldo. "[Letter from] Emerson to Carlyle, Concord, 6 May, 1856."
Emerson, Ralph Waldo. "Letter to Walt Whitman, Concord, Massachusetts, 21 July, 1855." The Walt Whitman Archive.
James, Henry. "Letter to Walt Whitman, November 16, 1856." The Walt Whitman Archive.
Lorca, Federico Garcia. "Ode to Walt Whitman."
Whitman, Walt. "By the Bivouac's Fitful Flame."
Whitman, Walt. "In Clouds Descending, In Midnight Sleep."
Whitman, Walt. "There Was A Child Went Forth."
Whitman, Walt. "Vigil Strange I Kept on the Field One Night."
Whitman, Walt. "Year That Trembled and Reel'd Beneath Me."

J-card description: Excerpts from a reading given by Allen Fisher in 1989. This includes poetry selected from 18 different books in the period of 1970-1983. This selection reproduces roughly half of a reading given by Allen Fisher of his SCRAM or the transformation of the concept of cities (selected poems 1970-1983). The reading was given above a noisy pub in London's West End on 13th January 1989 as part of Gilbert Adair's Sub-voicive Poetry series. The selection provides a broad range of constructive, conceptual and expressive examples from AF's work. The presentation of these poems is approximately in chronological order. ... [See images for complete description.]

Content.contents:
Side A contains a recording of Robert Hogg's June 9, 1995 reading of There Is No Falling at Black Sheep Books, Vancouver B.C., as aired on aradiofreerainforestape on Sept. 24, 1995. Side B is a continuation of Hogg's reading. Following this is a recording of Peggy Kelley reading from "Springs" on the Austin, Texas station KUT FM which aired in the summer of 1995. This broadcast was re-aired by radiofreerainforest on September 10, 1995.

Side A is blank. Side B contains a poetry reading by Robert Hogg in Ottawa, Ontario of his recently released poetry collection, There Is No Falling. Side A contains a recording of Robinson Jeffers reading his poems "To the Stone-Cutters," "Suicide's Stone," "Wise Men In Their Bad Hours," "Natural Music," "The Tower Beyond Tragedy," "Watch the Light Fade," "The Bloody Sire," and "The Truce and the Peace." The second half of Side A contains Theodore Roethke reading his poems "The Long Alley," and "The Shape of the Fire."

Side B contains W.H. Auden reading four sonnets from his collection "Journey to a War," "Song" from "Another Time," "Thanksgiving for a Habitat," "Autumn Song," "A Walk After Dark," "The Shield of Achilles," ", "Doggerel by a Senior Citizen," and "Moon Landing" interspersed with dialogue.

This is likely a mixtape of readings and the poets were not at the same event. This cassette recording was likely dubbed from other recordings.

Dates.notes: The Side A Robert Lowell reading was the last recorded reading before his death and was held on April 30, 1977. Source: https://www.lrb.co.uk/the-paper/v25/n17/michael-hofmann/his-own-prophet
Sylvia Plath opens recording on Side B by noting the date of recording was June 13, 1958.
Sylvia Plath opens second recording on Side B of recording by noting the date of recording was February 22, 1959.

Content.notes: Contents entry temporary. To be timestamped.
Content.contents:
Side A of tape consists of Robert Lowell reading his poems "Mr. Edwards and the Spiders," "Bringing a Turtle Home," "Returning Turtle," "Memories of West St and Lepke," "Central Park," "The March I," "The March II," "For John Berryman: After Reading His Last Dream Song" and "To Frank Parker." This is likely a recording of Lowell's last recorded reading before his death, which was given on April 30, 1977.

Side B consists first of a recording of Sylvia Plath reading her poems "Black Rook in Rainy Weather," "Maudlin," "Sow," "All The Dead Dears"  on June 13, 1958. Side B also contains a reading by Sylvia Plath on Feb 22, 1959 of "Full Fathom Five," "Watercolor of Grantchester Meadows," "Snakecharmer," "Point Shirley," "Departure," "I Want, I Want," "Lorelei," "Moonrise," "The Bull of Bendylaw," "The Hermit of Outermost House," and "Frog Autumn."

Creators.name: Lowell, Robert
Creators.notes: Robert Lowell reads his poems on Side A.

Creators.name: Plath, Sylvia
Creators.notes: Sylvia Plath reads her poetry on Side B.

Content.contents:
Side A of tape consists of a William Carlos Williams reading his poems "Burning the Christmas Greens," "The Visit," "The Lion," "Spring and All [By the road to the contagious hospital]," "This Is Just to Say," "Flowers by the Sea," "The Yachts," "Virtue," "Smell," "To Greet a Letter-Carrier," "At the Bar," "Perfection," "Fertile," "Picture of a Nude in a Machine Shop," "Venus over the Desert," and "Birth of Venus."

Side B consists of Marianne Moore reading her poems "In Lieu of the Lyre," "What are the Years," "The Mind is an Enchanting Thing," "A Carriage from Sweden," "He Digesteth Harde Yron," and "W.S. Landor," chatting with the audience.

Content.contents:
Side A consists of John Berryman reading The Dream Songs at a live poetry reading event. Berryman reads his poems "Dream Song 1," "Dream Song 5," "Dream Song 27," "Dream Song 69," "Dream Song 23," "Dream Song 22," "Dream Song 48," "Dream Song 17," "Dream Song 55," "Dream Song 53," "Dream Song 29," "Dream Song 8," "Dream Song 3: A Stimulant for an Old Beast," "Dream Song 36," "Dream Song 75," "Dream Song 34," "Dream Song 67," "Dream Song 71," and "Dream Song 77."

Side B consists of Randall Jarrell reading the following poems "After the Door Shuts, and the Footsteps Die," "A Camp in the Prussian Forest," "Gunner," "The Lines," "A Ward in the States," "In Montecito," "Next day," "Three Bills," and "The Player Piano."

Content.contents:
Interview of Robert Hogg and Ron Charach on CKCU (Concordia's university radio station). Hosted by Joy Gugeler and Elena Capello (spelling of name may be incorrect). Discuss Ron Charach's "Someone Else's Memoirs" and Robert Hogg's "There is no falling". 
Accompanying letter reads:
"June 28/94
Dear Prof. Hogg,
I apologize for the extensive delay in getting  you this tape - among other things, employment (Ass. [illegible] Inuit Art Quarterly Mag.) has waylaid me. However, I hope you enjoy the segment and that we have an opportunity to speak again. Best wishes for There is No Falling and future ventures.
Sincerely, Joy Gugeler (231-4996)

Content.contents: This recording consists of a guest lecture by Daphne Marlatt  in Warren Tallman's English 205 class at UBC. The lecture was given on Friday October 24, 1986. In the lecture Marlatt discusses Vancouver literary magazines including TISH, Blew Ointment, and The Georgia Straight. Marlatt also reads excepts from TISH by  poets Frank Davey, George Bowering, and Fred Wah.

Content.contents:
Side A: Tape consists of UBC English professor Warren Tallman giving a lecture to his ENGL 312: Studies in Poetry class on Robert Creeley. The lecture was held on November 17, 1986 in the Buchanan Buildings at UBC.

Side B: Tape consists of Warren Tallman continuing on his previous lecture about Robert Creeley to his ENGL 312: Studies in Poetry class. Tallman also discusses the work of Ezra Pound and Charles Olson, and sings popular music about the moon from the early 20th century. The lecture was held on November 19, 1986 in the Buchanan Buildings at UBC.

Content.contents:
Side A of this recording contains a recorded lecture by UBC English professor Warren Tallman from his undergraduate course, ENGL 205: Introduction to Poetry. This 50 minute lecture was recorded on November 19, 1986 in the Buchanan Buildings at UBC. In the recording Tallman lectures about the Romantic poets, with special attention to the works of William Wordsworth, Dorothy Wordsworth, and Samuel Taylor Coleridge. Tallman reads, recites, and offers commentary on the following poems and writings:  "Among All Lovely Things My Love Had Been," "A Slumber did by Spirit Seal," "Boat Stealing (excerpt from the Prelude)," "from The Prelude: Book 1: Childhood and School-time," "I Travelled among Unknown Men,"  "I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud,"  "Lines Composed a Few Miles above Tintern Abbey, On Revisiting the Banks of the Wye during a Tour. July 13, 1798," "Lucy Gray (or Solitude)," "Ode: Intimations of Immortality from Recollections of Early Childhood," "She Dwelt among the Untrodden Ways," "Strange Fits of Passion I have Known," "There was a Boy," "Three Years She Grew," and excerpts from Dorothy Wordsworth's journal. Unidentified students are occasionally audible throughout the recording answering questions posed by Tallman.

Side B of the recording contains a recorded lecture by UBC English professor Warren Tallman from his undergraduate course, ENGL 312: Studies in Poetry. This 50 minute lecture was recorded on November 25, 1986 in the Buchanan Buildings at UBC. In the recording Tallman defines and lectures about poetic vocabulary including discussions about the concepts of "vowel stress, consonant stress, primary stress, and juncture," Ezra Pound's "phanopoeia, melopoeia, logopoeia," Ernest Fenollosa's "metaphor as transfer of energy," "Mother Nature and Mother Tongue," "syntax and semantics," "abstract and abstract real," and "open form and close form poetry." Unidentified students are occasionally audible throughout the recording asking questions, answering questions, and contributing to the class discussion.

Creators.name: Tallman, Warren
Creators.notes: Recordist and lecturer in ENGL 205 class at UBC.

Content.contents:
Side A 1-4 consists of a recording of Ebbe Borregaard singing songs, playing the guitar, and reading poetry to Warren Tallman's English 303 class at UBC, circa 1970-72. 

Side A & B 3-2 consists of two parts of a recording in which Warren Tallman has a conversation with grade school teachers from the West Coast. The recording consists of teachers reading a "statement of education" followed by questions and comments from Warren Tallman and other teachers. This event was likely held in Warren Tallman's private residence, circa 1971-72.

Content.contents:
Side A of the recording contains a recorded guest poetry reading and lecture by bill bissett in UBC English professor Warren Tallman's undergraduate course, ENGL 312: Studies in Poetry. This 50 minute lecture was recorded on November 24, 1986 in the Buchanan Buildings at UBC. In the recording an unknown speaker introduces bill bissett, who then performs a chant, reads selections from his poetry collection Seagull on Yonge Street, and tells the class the origin story of the name bissett.

Side B consists of Warren Tallman reading an early audio draft of what would become his Retirement Speech, "How to Play Career and Win." The date of this recording is unknown, but was possibly recorded on November 24, 1986 as well.

Content.contents:
This tape copy contains a recording the first of three guest lectures Robert Creeley gave at Warren and Ellen Tallman's house on 37th Street, Vancouver, B.C. This particular lecture was recorded on August 26, 1962. The following two lectures were given on August 28 and August 29, 1962. These two lectures were also recorded, and are available in the Frank Davey fonds of the SoundBox Collection (2014.002.001). Frank Davey recorded the event and references the event in his book When TISH Happens (p. 160-2).

In this lecture Robert Creeley discusses the question, "what is poetry?" He draws on the definitions of many writers and poets including Joshua Whatmough, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Robert Conquest, Ezra Pound, Edward Sapir, Walt Whitman, and William Carlos Williams. Warren Tallman and various students and guests including George Bowering occasionally ask questions.

Creators.name: Bowering, George
Creators.notes: Unconfirmed. George Bowering seems to have been in attendance and is heard in the audience asking a question. Frank Davey confirms that George Bowering was present at this event in his book "When TISH Happens" (p. 160-2).

Creators.name: Davey, Frank
Creators.notes: Frank Davey recalls being present at this event in his book "When TISH Happens" (p. 160-2).

Location.notes: This recording contains one of three lectures Robert Creeley gave at Warren and Ellen Tallmans' house on 37th Street in Vancouver, B.C. on Aug 26, 28, 29, 1962. Frank Davey refers to this event in When TISH Happens (p. 160-2).

Related_Works.citation: Coleridge, Samuel Taylor. “Recapituation, and Summary Of the Characteristics of Shakespeare’s Dramas.” In Shakespeare, Ben Jonson, Beaumont and Fletcher.
Conquest, Robert. The Pasternak Affair: Courage of Genius; A Documentary Report. Lippincott, 1962.
Sapir, Edward. “Language and Literature.” In Language: An Introduction to the Study of Speech. Harcourt, Brace & World, 1921.
Whatmough, Joshua. Language: A Modern Synthesis. St Martin’s Press, 1956.
Whitman, Walt. “A Backward Glance.” Leaves of Grass.
Williams, William Carlos. “Author’s Introduction (The Wedge).” Selected Essays of Williams Carlos Williams. New Directions Publishing Corporation, 2009.

Content.contents:
This recording consists of two unrelated recordings, on Side A and Side B. 

Side A contains a recording called "West Coast with Stan and Gladys" in which UBC English professor Warren Tallman has a conversation with Stan Persky and G. Maria Hindmarch in his living room in Vancouver. The conversation was meant to establish the basic facts and context for a book Tallman was commissioned to write about West Coast Poetry.

Side B contains a recording of Warren Tallman interviewing Daphne Marlatt about her recently published poetry collection Leaf Leaf/s (1968). In the recording Marlatt both discusses and reads excerpts from Leaf Leaf/s.

Related_Works.citation: Marlatt, Daphne. Leaf Leaf/s. Black Sparrow Press, 1968.

Content.contents: In this recording, Daphne Marlatt reads selections from her first collection, Frames of a story (1968), and is interviewed by Warren Tallman about her process and inspiration in writing the collection. The interview may have been conducted in preparation for a paid review by Warren Tallman for Ryerson Press, although such a review never seems to have been written. The interview was conducted and recorded in December 1968 in Warren Tallman’s home.

Location.notes: Warren Tallman's interview of Daphne Marlatt took place in his house on 37th Street in Vancouver, B.C.

Dates.notes: Warren Tallman references this event in his retirement speech, "How To Play Career and Win" (In the Midst, 253).

Notes.note: Warren Tallman refers to this event in his book In the Midst: "In 1967 I taught a graduate Walt Whitman course. We put on a Whitman reading, really a group effort if ever there was one. So I gave an identical first class mark to each and all 12 participants. Bill Robbins frowned. The frown stayed on. In the 18 years since then my applications to teach graduate courses have been successful only twice, most recently, courtesy Ian Ross. I however, have taught a contemporary poetry course since 1959 in an on-campus, or at-home, or somewhere downtown, sort of way, aided and abetted for many years by Ellen, Karen, and Ken and a long parade of students, student poets, and poet friends, some of whom are here right now." (In the Midst, "How To Play Career and Win," 253). https://www-deslibris-ca.ezproxy.library.ubc.ca/ID/409392

Content.contents: This recording contains the audio from a public event hosted and performed by the graduate students of Warren Tallman's Walt Whitman English class in 1967. The poetry reading consists of approximately 12 students reading the poems and prose of Walt Whitman. Commercially recorded Civil War music is also played during a short intermission during the reading.

Creators.name: Tallman, Warren
Creators.notes: Warren Tallman was the professor of this graduate class and recorded this reading as organized by the students in that class. His voice is not present on the recording.

Content.contents:
Side A, track 1-4 consists of a poetry reading by an unknown speaker, likely recorded in the class of Warren Tallman.

Side A, track 3-2 consists of a mixtape of dubbed music and poetry readings. Track list consists of the following: Béla Bartók's "Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta", Ezra Pound reading Cantos I and IV, "I Threw It All Away" by Bob Dylan, "Blue In Green" by Miles Davis, "Summertime" and "Piece of My Heart" by Janis Joplin, "Catch the Wind" by Donovan, "Break on Through (To the Other Side)" and "Light My Fire" by the Doors, and Charles Olson reading "Maximus by Himself," "Variations Done for Gerald Van De Wiele," and "As the Dead Prey Upon Us." Warren Tallman can be heard talking occasionally while he is dubbing the music.

Content.contents:
Side A of this recording contains a lecture by Warren Tallman in his ENGL 205: Introduction to Poetry class at UBC. The lecture was recorded on November 24, 1986, likely in one of the classrooms in the Buchanan Building at UBC, Vancouver. In the lecture Warren Tallman discusses the work of poet William Blake while integrating discussions of various poetic vocabulary including the eidetic. Warren Tallman also reads, or possibly recites, multiple poems of Blake's. Unknown students are occasionally heard asking questions.

Side B of this recording contains a lecture by Warren Tallman in his ENGL 205: Introduction to Poetry class at UBC. The lecture was recorded on November 26, 1986, likely in one of the classrooms in the Buchanan Building at UBC, Vancouver. In the lecture Warren Tallman discusses poetic vocabulary such as phanopoeia, melopoeia, and logopoeia, Mother Earth and Mother Tongue, transfer of energy, numinous poets, oracular poets, the abstract, synchronicity, and the gnostic. Tallman also discusses the work of Ernest Fenollosa, Ezra Pound, WIlliam Carlos Williams, Charles Olson, and Robert Creeley. Unknown students are occasionally heard asking questions.

Creators.name: Tallman, Warren
Creators.notes: Recordist and lecturer in ENGL 205 class at UBC.

Location.venue: Buchanan Building, University of British Columbia

Contributors.name: Blake, William
Contributors.notes: Warren Tallman reads and discusses the poems of William Blake in the Side A lecture.
